bibl.title: Letter from Allan Jennings to Joseph A. LePrince, July 20, 1908 [Enclosed in KAGB0130]

div1.p: Jennings gives a report of how Phinotas Oil affects the pupa stage in the immature mosquito. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Allan Jennings to Joseph A. LePrince, July 20, 1908 [Enclosed in KAGB0130]
div1.opener:
When replying refer to
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
DEPARTMENT OF SANITATION
------
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY INSPECTOR
ANCON, C. Z.
July 20th, 1908.
Mr. J. A. LePrince,
Chief Sanitary Inspector,
Ancon.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I have completed a series of tests of Phinotas Oil to
determine as far as possible the character and quality of the stock
now hand and to compare it with the samples of the oil recently sub-
mitted to you by the Manufacturers.

The samples tested were as follows, (all from different
barrels and opened):
Sample “A” (
/from Manufacturers.
Sample “B” (
Sample Ancon I.Barrel opened by breaking head. Barrel
nearly empty when sample was taken.
Sample Ancon II.Barrel opened by head and fresh when taken.
Sample Empire I.Barrel opened by head and half empty.
(Several days exposed).
Sample Empire II.Barrel freshly opened by head. Same as used
in experiments on lagoon by R. L. Turner.
Sample Bas ObispoDrawn from stop cock.
Sample Corosal.Barrel recently opened by head.

The variation as to character and action was found to be
considerable but the samples fall into three classes, as follows:
FIRST.That in which a complete emulsion is immediately produced,
the body of the water completely filled with milky clouds and
little or no precipitate thrown down with no film formed on sur-
face.
SECOND.That in which there is partial emulsification, a more or
less heavy white precipitate which remains on the bottom if not
disturged, with unbroken globules of oil. There is usually on oily film
with milky streaks or clouds and small globules of oil. Sometimes
also a slight cloudiness often barely perceivable.
THIRD.That in which there is no emulsification or cloudiness and
no precipitate but a heavy oily film interspersed with more or
less heavy, well-defined globules.

In the action of the various samples there was more or less
variation from these types but in the main the classes were well-defined.

The tests were made with tap water, in glass containers hold-
ing 1000 C. C. measured with great accuracy and the oil measured by means of
a pipette giving exact fractions of a C. C. These measurements were also
frequently checked and verified.

The tests show occasional irregularities in the comparison of
different samples at the various strengths and conditions but frequent check
tests bore out the following conclusions: That Class I, that in which emul-
sification is complete and a milky could, more or less dense according to
- 3 -
strength of the solution, permeates the entire body of the water, shows
a decided superiority over the other two classes. This is marked ex-
cept in the tests where dilution was high 1/20,000 and 1/40,000, where
the action of all becomes uncertain and the varying resistance of indi-
vidual larvae comes into play.

Where a solution of 1 part Phinotas to 20 parts of water
was made and then introduced into container with larvae and enough water
to bring strength to the desired point, the action was more rapid than
when the same quantity was introduced directly into the whole body of the
water. This is doubtless due to the more rapid diffusion through the
bodn of the water. In these tests also Class I showed its superiority
at the different strengths used.

To test duration of efficiency a solution was made of
one (1) part Phinotas to eight thousand (8,000) of water and exposed
indoors for sixty-four (64) hours before larvae were introduced. A mark-
ed deterioration was noted, the larvae living many hours longer than
where even a weaker solution is made and tested at once.

At one (1) to five thousand (5,000) and exposed forty-
eight (48) hours the deterioration was at least as marked.

In these tests Class I showed as a whole superiority to
the other classes.

A small quantity of each of several samples was exposed in
shallow dishes for forty-eight (48) hours indoors and then tested with
the result that all classes suffered by the exposure but in varying de-
gree, as might have been expected those which had been most exposed be-
- 4 -
fore sample was taken showed least deterioration.

Sample “A”, Class I, in particular showed the greatest
change and three others by this test belonged in another class.

To summarize: Those samples falling in Class I showed
the greatest efficiency as well as equally long duration. Classes II
and III show an irregularity of action which is borne out by field tests
of Phinotas known to show same characteristics.

Sample “B”, Class III, which is recommended by the manu-
facturer, is shown to be of doubtful efficiency and their statement (made
in letter of June 16th, 1908, that “The Phinotas Oil we sent you being
only partially soluble”) if it applies to their first shipment is clearly
incorrect and this fact can be substantiated. I have tested in laboratory
and witnessed field tests of their earlier shipment or shipments that were
taken at random and was perfectly soluble and very efficient. With later
shipments this has not been the case and the action so irregular as to
cause great undertainty in its use in the field.

I have ascertained that the sample of Phinotas, labelled
Ancon II, was taken from a barrel constituting a portion of the above ship-
ment and this bears out the statement.

A drawback to the indiscriminate use of Phinotas Oil is
the absence of any effect upon pupae at ordinary and economical strengths.
I believe this to be due to the fact that in the pupa stage the immature
mosquito does not eat and no passage of a poisonous substance into the
body through the moutn is possible. Unless a heavy oily film rests upon
- 5 -
the surface to clog the breathing orifices, the pupa is unaffected or
unless the caustic action of the substance used is great enough to pene-
trate the integument. This is not the case with Phinotas unless used
at a prohibitive strength.

I consider the preparation especially useful used in
full strength in running water, even along the edges of good sized streams
where quick action is desired and can be obtained from Class I. In such
situations crude oil is not available as it is floated off and dissipated
before it has lived to act. In places also where constant overflowing of
the body of water due to rains renders constant care necessary, Phinotas
is at least as useful and may have frequently some advantages over the
crude oil.

As its permanence seems to be very difficult, field tests
having shown breeding to begin within two days after application, it is in
this inferior to crude oil, besides which its poisonous effect upon fish
is a drawback to its use in many instances.

A point in its favor is the small bulk and consequent economy
in handling when used in full strength. I would especially recommend that
all Phinotas Oil used at all stations be drawn from the barrel by means of
a stopcock as all deterioration from exposure will thus be avoided.
Very respectfully,
(Sgd) ALLAN H. JENNINGS.
O

row.cell:
More or less cloudiness
according to strength.

Oil film after more or
less milky.

div1.p:
July 31, 1908
Col. W. C. Gorgas
In re Phinstas oil to
kill mosquito larvae
